vague_description: A chemistry teacher needs to determine the optimal number of two unique experiments to perform given resource constraints and production limits.
detailed_description: A chemistry teacher teaches her students two experiments, experiment 1 and experiment 2. In experiment 1, \param{Red1} units of the red liquid and \param{Blue1} units of the blue liquid mix to create \param{Green1} units of green gas. In experiment 2, \param{Red2} units of the red liquid and \param{Blue2} units of the blue liquid mix to create \param{Green2} units of green gas. In addition, experiment 1 produces \param{Smelly1} units of smelly gas while experiment 2 produces \param{Smelly2} units of smelly gas. The lab has available \param{TotalRed} units of red liquid and \param{TotalBlue} units of blue liquid. If at most \param{MaxSmelly} units of smelly gas can be produced, how many experiments of each should be done to maximize the total amount of green gas produced?
target_objective: Maximize the total amount of green gas produced from both experiments
target_constraints: Total units of red liquid used in both experiments cannot exceed TotalRed
Total units of blue liquid used in both experiments cannot exceed TotalBlue
Total units of smelly gas produced from both experiments cannot exceed MaxSmelly
target_parameters: Units of the red liquid mixed in experiment 1
Units of the blue liquid mixed in experiment 1
Units of green gas produced in experiment 1
Units of smelly gas produced in experiment 1
Units of the red liquid mixed in experiment 2
Units of the blue liquid mixed in experiment 2
Units of green gas produced in experiment 2
Units of smelly gas produced in experiment 2
Total units of red liquid available
Total units of blue liquid available
Maximum units of smelly gas allowed
